concept.title: Data Visibilities
concept.shortdesc: Data visibilities identify the privacy requirements for data.

conbody.p: All data stored in PHEMI Central is protected with Visibilities, which are user-defined labels that specify the sensitivity of data. For example, PII (Personally Identifiable Information) is a common label, that can be applied to data about an individual to indicate its sensitivity, such as a Name. Another example, is NonPII (Non-PII) labels, such as an individuals weight or eye colour.
PHEMI Central enables the creation of custom Data Visibilities to meet an organization's needs around data protection through its Management Console.

When a Data Policy is defined for a Data Source, it can be configured with any number of Visibilities so that the data is stored with these labels attached to the data. Additionally, Data Processing Functions can apply Visibilities at a fine-grained level, enabling cell-level data protection.
predefines three visibilities pertaining to privacy:

row.entry: Sensitive data that contains identifying information. Such data should be secured and available only to authorized personnel.
Sensitive data that has been transformed and masked to remove identifying information
Data that does not contain sensitive or identifying data.

conbody.p: You can define additional data visibilities to suit your organization's needs. Possible examples are CONFIDENTIAL to identify data that is sensitive and requires a user to a certain level of access or certification to access, PII to identify Personally Identifiable Information, PHI to identify personal health information, or SECRET to identify especially sensitive material.
conbody.note: Once defined, a data visibility may be neither edited nor deleted.
conbody.p: The data visibilities specified for a data source are referred to in access policies and matched against user authorizations to determine what actions, if any, a given user is allowed to perform on the data.

Any data visibility defined in the system can be used by a Data Processing Function (DPF) to tag data elements, or cells, derived by the DPF. For example, the Social Security Number extracted from a health record can be tagged CONFIDENTIAL if that data visibility has been defined in the system. This mechanism provides "cell-level" privacy protection.
